review:
Inside is an amazing game that really grabs you right from the start. The dark visuals and creepy sounds create a tense atmosphere that pulls you in. The puzzles are smart and gradually get trickier, keeping you on your toes.
The story is told without a lot of dialogue, but it‚Äôs still powerful and makes you think. With its simple but striking art style, Inside offers a unique and unforgettable experience. It‚Äôs definitely a must-play for anyone who loves indie games!

Absolutely beautiful game in terms of aesthetics and story, and while the movement speed/animation/physics takes a little getting used to, it's actually VERY satisfying. I wasted a good amount of time just making the character turn around, hop, run, etc... just because it was so fun to watch. Scratched my brain very nicely. I also just cannot say enough about the storytelling and worldbuilding; it's intriguing and mysterious and so well made in the way it just unfolds throughout the play. I went into this without reading anything about the game (bought as a bundle on a pretty big discount) and was just stunned.

The only downside is, really, that because I played this first, I couldn't enjoy Limbo. At all. It just seemed like the clunky, awkward brother of Inside that tags along to hangouts and sours the mood. Every time I jump or interact with objects in Limbo I can't help but think "This would feel so much better in Inside." So there's that. If you have the choice, play Limbo first. Otherwise, Inside will probably ruin that experience :')

For having no dialogue, this game has a pretty insane plot. I like this style of game where you just progress through a naturally flowing series of areas as the environment around you tells a story. Limbo is a great example of this, and to an extent Little Nightmares as well. If you're thinking of picking this one up, it's worth it, I really enjoyed playing this.

[h1][b] TLDR: "We have Little Nightmares at home" vibe. A good and creepy setting, but LN1 and 2 are leagues better. [/b] [/h1]

[h1]PROS: [/h1]
‚úÖDark and unsettling atmosphere
‚úÖGenerally good logical puzzles

[h1]CONS: [/h1]
‚ûñAll achievements are missable 
‚ûñSome occasional backtracking slog
‚ûñEntirely new puzzle elements at the very end throw out everything you‚Äôve learned so far
‚ûñUnclear plot


SPOOKTOBER REVIEW #1
[h1] [b] Content (Game world/Narrative/Length) ‚Äì [7/10] [/b] [/h1]
Game World: Inside‚Äôs game world is dark, unsettling, and just plain creepy. The developer also made Limbo, which is similar to Inside, but I would say that Inside is also very similar to Little Nightmares (LN). Like LN, Inside is a side-scrolling dark/horror themed game with a subtle plot and no speaking parts. In Inside you play as a nameless boy who must evade captors to go‚Ä¶.somewhere.

Narrative: LN at the very least had a more concrete direction in which the game shepherded the player. In Inside, everything is pretty much left up to interpretation. You have no real idea what is happening and even the ending(s) don‚Äôt do much to help. 
Overall, I wasn‚Äôt a fan of how the game left me with more questions than answers and despite the well-made world itself, the lack of a narrative or at the very least an explanation kind of made the experience not worth it. 

Length: This is a short game and can be completed in 3.5 hours, assuming you don‚Äôt go for the 2nd ending. 

[h1][b] Gameplay (Mechanics/Difficulty) ‚Äì [6/10] [/b] [/h1]
Mechanics: The only mechanics that Inside has are puzzle-oriented. Your control scheme is pretty much jump and grab/interact. I found the puzzles to be generally creative and utilizing the game world well. 
Puzzles generally consist of moving objects to gain a higher ground, timing oriented jumps/object interaction, evading enemies by either hiding or using the environment creatively, and interacting with the environment. There wasn‚Äôt much platforming here and while you can fail and will die (probably a lot), I found the checkpoint system forgiving enough. 
As the boy you spend about 3 hours learning various aspects of how puzzles interact with the world, then the last 30 minutes everything you learned is thrown out because you control a new character. I felt that this kind of took away from the ‚ÄúEscape‚Äù setting that you were in because while you‚Äôre trying to escape the zone, you are also fumbling around re-learning concepts all over again. It just makes a really strange setting even stranger but for the wrong reasons. 

Difficulty: Throughout the game there were about 2 or 3 puzzles that really made me stuck, but overall as far as the difficulty it's kind of like Portal where if you look around enough, you‚Äôll probably start to piece together what you need to do. 

[h1] [b] Graphics (Quality/Performance) ‚Äì [7/10] [/b] [/h1]
Quality: Inside has some great graphics and physics. I especially loved the part where you smash an NPC and are covered in viscera until you go in the water. Very nice touches and also good physics. 

Performance: From a pure technical side, there is really only the option to do resolution and brightness. I would have at the very least wanted a frame limiter as there is no reason for me to run the game at a constant 250 FPS. Regardless, Inside lacks that and that‚Äôs what I ran the game at. No stuttering or bugs of any kind. 
i9-13900KF | RTX 4090 | 64GB RAM | 1440p @ 240hz | installed on SSD

[h1] [b] Audio (Sound Effects/Music) ‚Äì [7/10] [/b] [/h1]
Sound Effects: Well done, fits perfectly within the setting of being unsettling. There is no voice acting in this game other than NPC grunts and other sounds of exertion. The best part of the sound effects is bringing the game world to life with the sound of rain, footsteps, and metallic chain clinkings. 

Music: Inside didn‚Äôt really have a noticeable soundtrack. There were parts where some slight musical notes occurred, but nothing worth noting here. 

[h1] [b] Replay Factor (Longevity) ‚Äì [3/10] [/b] [/h1]
The only reason to replay this is to get the alternate ending and for all (missable) achievements. 

[h1] [b] Final Verdict ‚Äì [6/10] [/b] [/h1]
If you like Little Nightmares, you should play Inside. I personally found LN 1 and 2 to be better than Inside from every aspect. I think the biggest reason why I prefer LN over Inside is that I have no idea what is happening in Inside. While at the ending of LN, especially #2, my mind was blown. I‚Äôm all for subtle endings that leave the meaning up to player interpretation, but I didn‚Äôt feel a strong enough connection to anything that really happened throughout the game. 
Still, Inside is worth giving a shot if you enjoy these types of creepy side-scrolling games. 

[h1] [b] Recommend? [Y/N] [/b] [/h1]
[h1]Yes[/h1]

This review should be treated as a sort of sequel to my review of the developer's previous game, Limbo, which I reviewed negatively. I actually bought this because I wanted it, instead of Limbo which ended up in my library ~10 years ago via an old school Humble Bundle. If you're not old enough to remember those, you'd get 7-8 indie games for whatever you wanted to pay, even 0.01. Most of the games on offer were trashy and well past their prime time for sales, but they'd sometimes contain gems.

Inside fixes the main problem that Limbo has - that it doesn't do anything of note with the mood that it creates. In contrast, Inside has something to say that, at least by 2016 standards, isn't the standard indie platformer regurgitation of Psychology/Sociology 101. It does scare you, it contains plenty of dark humour, the puzzles make more sense and it tones down the abstraction just enough.

I am particularly impressed by the animations, which give me strong Prince of Persia vibes. Inside has loads of cool platformer gimmicks that could, in a way, define it as a tech (design?) demo - there is so much potential here for similar mechanics in a larger, perhaps less minimalistic game. As a game, the puzzles are mostly process of elimination stuff, rather than anything to get your brain turning. As a piece of art, it's amazing. 

But that's the thing. While I enjoy Inside FAR more than Limbo, like most indies of that era, it lingers on "the message" far too much at the expense of the gameplay. Having said that, it's incredibly satisfying to play and a nice quiet break from the Doom binge I've been on recently.

Anyway, please can someone look at what PC platformers were doing in the mid-late 90s and... well do that but with the puzzles and "message" seen here in Inside. There's a HUGE gap in the market for that. Jazz Jackrabbit 2, from 1998, feels more modern than most if not all platformers released today, even in 2024. (Outside of Nintendo of course)

...**** it, maybe I'll make that game. Famous last words: How hard can it be?

Inside is a hauntingly beautiful experience that transcends traditional gaming. While the gameplay is solid‚Äîoffering clever puzzles and tight platforming‚Äîthe true gem lies in its disturbingly atmospheric world and unsettling narrative. From the moment you step into its shadowy landscape, you're enveloped in a sense of dread and curiosity that keeps you engaged.

The visuals are striking, with a minimalist aesthetic that complements the grim setting perfectly. Each environment tells its own story, filled with eerie details that invite exploration yet leave you feeling vulnerable. The sound design further enhances this experience, with ambient noises that evoke a constant sense of unease.

As for the plot, it‚Äôs a mind-bending journey that defies conventional storytelling. Without giving too much away, the narrative is filled with surreal twists that provoke thought long after the credits roll. It‚Äôs one of those stories that makes you question everything you‚Äôve experienced and leaves you pondering the deeper themes of control and conformity.

Overall, Inside is a solid 8/10. It masterfully combines gameplay and atmosphere into a gripping, immersive experience. If you‚Äôre looking for a game that will challenge your mind and unsettle your spirit, this is a must-play.

I press 'X' and a small, childlike, faceless silhouetted avatar tumbles down a cliff-edge and lands on a mysterious, barren 2D landscape. No foreshadowing, no context, nothing.

I move the left analog stick to the right and he starts to walk. His tiny feet splash through murky puddles as he attempts to navigate his way through a seemingly uninhabited forest, before encountering two ominous characters, after exiting a large truck, slightly off the beaten path. They seem to be looking for something. Their flashlights are the only things that light up the surrounding darkness. I'm not sure why, but it's probably for the best that they don't know I'm here. I keep moving, stealthily taking cover behind anything I pass; trees, boulders, abandoned RVs, anything I can find, as I descend downwards alongside an apparent country road. It's not long before my footprints are discovered by their canine companions, and a chase ensues. I have no idea what's happening, but my instinct is to run.

I run for miles. It turns out there's many more of these figures, and they all have vehicles, so I must utilize everything in my immediate vicinity to remain hidden. I jump fences, climb foothills and power through water-drenched crevices as I avoid my mysterious pursuers' line-of-sight, before landing at the door of a dilapidated warehouse located on the outskirts of an abandoned industrial estate.

As I progress through the interconnected rooms of this gigantic warehouse, I'm faced with incredibly unusual, yet creatively original puzzles, like telepathically manipulating the movements of strangely deformed looking citizens, by standing on top of a dead pig and placing my head into a helmet-like device. Or by playing some sort of elaborate game of musical chairs, as I attempt to blend into the foreground with other slave-like remnants under the preying eye of tyrannical overseeers, as we shuffle in formation down an assembly line of a manufacturing plant, eerily similar to those seen in 'Another Brick in the Wall', or even Nazi Germany concentration camps.

Once I break out into the exterior of the manufacturing plant, and continue my journey through a seemingly fallen society, traversing derelict, abbatoir-like farms, and swimming in leech-infested waters, I'm captivated by Inside's minimalistic storytelling, and how it conveys its narrative through incredible animations and theatrical physics. 

The further I progress, the more I get the recurring feeling that I'm exploring a world completely and utterly void of life in the traditional sense. A distant monochromatic eeriness tells the story of something that was once here but hasn't been for a very long time.
Due to the fact the entirety of the game takes place over the course of one night, as dawn starts to rise, and after a few more exaggerated gruesome deaths, and genuinely unsettling clutch chase scenes, resulting in death only ever feeling like a hair's breath away, I finally encounter a gigantic blob of human flesh, functioning as a network, hidden in the depths of a secret underground facility, surrounded by a large group of fascinated scientists who had been conducting experiments on the game's population. It's now my duty to integrate myself into the human blob, assume the role of the now self-aware network, escape the facility by any means necessary, and seek potential freedom from the oppressive overseers.    

Due to the vagueness of the game's narrative, as all in-game conciousness; such as farm-life, citizens, and even the player character, slowly gravitates towards this network hive-mind near the games end, in its attempts to become sentient, led many to believe the player character is under the control of an unseen force like the aforementioned hive-mind. Some believe the unseen force is the game player themselves. Some have even gone as far as to speculate the player character being an anomoly in the corrupt facility's network and therefore a possible representation of free will. 

My personal opinion is the beauty in its narrative or lack thereof lies in its ambiguity, and having a fixed plotline could go so far as to tarnish what may seem like simply a sequel to Playground Games' 2008 2D side-scroller Limbo.
However, if you dig a little deeper, you can uncover multiple layers of staggering storytelling complexity that many games in this genre haven't before touched on. Inside is a game that can never be fully appreciated unless played completely blind in the first playthrough, with no prior research. It's also far more than what it appears on the surface, although its surface is still incredibly beautiful.

I purchased LIMBO on sale for $2, tried it, and hated it. It was one of the most boring games I‚Äôve ever played. So, when INSIDE was recommended to me as a better game I thought ‚ÄúWhat the heck? $5 on sale, it can't get much worse‚Äù. It can. And it did.

Visuals 6/10
The colors were better than LIMBO, but still lacked diversity.
- The constant grays made the whole game feel dull. I would have loved a slight color shift for each of the different building sections (1, 2, 3, 4) to make each part distinct
- The backgrounds were more detailed and interesting compared to LIMBO
- I would have loved little pops of red to tie in the boy you play as to the world. The yellow wires and pink bars did a great job of grabbing attention, I would have loved to see more of that

Audio 3/10
There was nothing that stood out about the audio/atmosphere. It just felt like generic and empty space.
- The dogs were loud AF. There is audio control but it is master volume, not specific to ambience vs sound effects
- The ambience wasn‚Äôt obviously different depending on the space. It would have been cooler if there was specific sound triggers to differentiate the sections

Gameplay 4/10
There was potential for a lot of innovative and interesting mechanics, but nothing was fleshed out.
- Similar to LIMBO, there was a lot of box pushing, which gets old after 5 min--let alone 3 hours
- The mind control was one of the best mechanics that was very unique to INSIDE and provided information about the world
- Some of the most compelling mechanics were only used once and then never seen again. For example: The pig with the leech, the chicks in the barn, walking in line with other victims and the security robots with spotlight eyes that are LITERALLY in the banner for the game

Horror 3/10
This was not a horror game. Anything that was remotely horrific was underwhelming, and it made INSIDE feel like more of a puzzle game than anything else.
- These were the scariest aspects of the game:
The banging door you needed 20 people to open. I was horrified by the loud sounds but the moment I entered the room and realized it was just a shockwave mechanism I was no longer scared.
The underwater scenes. I was worried there would be a giant fish/shark creature attacking me, but instead it was a small siren creature. Once I realized there was nothing else in the water, it wasn‚Äôt scary at all.
The dogs. This fear came from the fact that their audio is SO FUCKING LOUD, and they get very close to the character right before you make your escape.
- Most of these ‚Äúscary‚Äù aspects really just come from the fear of the unknown, which makes this game much less enjoyable during a replay due to the fact you know what/where everything is

Story 0/10
There are many games in existence with an open-ended story that is up to interpretation of the viewers. This is not one of those games. 
- The game began very similarly to LIMBO with a boy awakening in a forest area. This opening feels uninspired and lacking. It would have been much more interesting to see the character run away from home and travel through his hometown, rather than in a random forest with no meaning in the plot
- The main part of the game takes place in flooded and machine filled laboratories. This can be interesting for a bit, but after spending hours in it, it no longer has intrigue. The game should include a variety of environments, like expanding on the farmland with infested animals or even--I don‚Äôt know--THE FOREST
-INSIDE and LIMBO share the honor of having an abrupt and questionable ending, both including smashing through a wall to emerge in the forest and having no further movement until the credits roll

Summary 3/10
Again Playdead comes through with another boring, box-pushing ‚Äúhorror‚Äù game. Stripped to its bones it is practically a carbon copy of LIMBO and is definitely not worth $20. Thank you for your time, and to all a goodnight.

INSIDE is an Masterpiece of gaming, that is the first thing you will hear about this game.

But what it's surprise me is how such a creative experience it's is. There no cheap happy or sad moments (or any moments of that type at all), there not any line of dialogue, it's the most muted color palette you can think without being grey scale.  There no faces to express feelings on the characters. Music is almost beat-less. THIS IS THE MOST MINIMALIST GAME YOU CAN PLAY. And still delivers a top-notch experience from beginning to end.  it' intrigue you enough that you can play it easy on one sitting. 

When you study filming, you found out there tools to tell stories and these tools where implemented because there weren't too many resources to tell a Story (mostly old movies). PLAYDEAD STUDIOS implement this cinematic language so well, Like Bresson avoid to used emotional manipulative language to tell a story, or Tarkovsky weight of atmosphere on scene.  This game is so well done that they give you the whole short experience and you feel that there not a moment wasted on the whole game. i'm impressed too that there horror in the game and they don't add a  jump scare that feel intentional or forced. everything come at certain moment that i still debatable that if they are jump scares or not, but there moments that feels like jump scares. 

There things i don't like for matter of taste like [spoiler] that one puzzle of the hook, the sirens and using your feet to attracted his/her position [/spoiler] or [spoiler] the ambiguous ending [/spoiler] but these decision goes perfect with the experience even if they are not my taste. 


I see games like this, Outer Wilds and Subnautica as the future of storytelling. INSIDE take what games like Another World, Flashback or Oddworld and make the perfect game for the genre. i can't imagine the people who are waiting for a sequel or another game from the studio since 2016.

What I felt during gameplay :

1. Curiosity
2. Fear
3. Sadness
4. Mildly Aroused

This is quite simply one of the most hauntingly beautiful puzzle-platformers I've ever played. INSIDE is devoid of dialogue, let alone definitive answers, but its tight, thought-provoking gameplay will keep you pushing forward at every turn. What are you running from? Why are you in danger? Who even are you? Honestly, when the game is this good, does it even matter?

Even across its 3-5-hour span of standard gameplay, you're not prepared for how this all comes together as well. The shocking ending is bound to stick with you, leaving you simultaneously triumphant and disturbed. I don't normally write reviews for games, but felt compelled to for this one. Let's start with one of the best aspects of this game... it only requires one hand to play it. That means beer, wine, cocktails, snacks, etc. are all a welcomed accompaniment. While that may be a turn-off for those looking for a more tactile-m&k skill based experience, that is not the point of this game. You're thrown into a strange, eerie, and melancholy world as a defenseless yet clever young boy, with danger lurking around every corner. You have nothing but wit and problem solving as your tools of advancing through to the next stages of the game. The puzzles were challenging enough, without taking too long to solve. The sounds in this game are simple awesome, creating the right amount of tension, peacefulness, & awareness for each given scenario. There's only been a handful of simple games like this that I've played that were able to convey so much in such a short amount of time, Outer Wilds is similar one that comes to mind. It was a fairly shorter play through, taking me about 5 hours to complete in 3 sittings. One of the cooler aspects of this game is the world it's set in posses many questions, and the ending... leaves you with even more. 10/10

Inside is a game that deserves to stay in your memory for a long time. It's more than just a platformer; it's an interactive experience that immerses you in a bleak, alienated world where every step induces anxiety and makes you feel genuine danger.

The story is told without words, and this is one of those cases where less is more. No dialogues, no explanations‚Äîjust you, the boy, and this world that seems to be crafted from the darkest corners of human imagination. You quickly realize that in this world, you are just a small part of something much bigger, sinister, and incomprehensible.

The gameplay in Inside is simple but expertly designed. The puzzles are well-integrated into the gameplay, and none of them feel artificial. They make the game feel rich, and each solution brings a sense of relief, but also a new wave of fear‚Äîwhat's next?

The game's visual design is a masterpiece on its own. Each scene is a painting where shadows play the leading role. Just a few colors, but they are used so masterfully that they convey more emotions than dozens of details. The atmosphere is created not only through graphics but also through sound design. Silence, punctuated by eerie sounds and rare musical accents, creates a sense of complete isolation.

The game's ending is a story in itself. It leaves more questions than answers, making you ponder what you've just experienced. It's the kind of ending that makes you want to discuss it with others, searching for meaning and clues.

Inside is a game that's hard to forget. It doesn't just entertain but also makes you think. It's perfect for those who appreciate deep, atmospheric stories where what's left unsaid is more important than what's explicitly shown.

Inside, from the creators of Limbo, has always held a special place in my gaming history. Playing it when I was younger left a lasting impression, and revisiting it now only deepens my appreciation for its artistry and storytelling. The game remains a testament to how a minimalist approach can result in an incredibly profound experience.

Gameplay and Atmosphere:
Inside is a masterclass in atmospheric storytelling and environmental design. From the very start, the game draws you into a dystopian world with its hauntingly silent and oppressive ambiance. The gameplay is straightforward yet deeply engaging, with a focus on puzzle-platforming and exploration. Each segment of the game introduces new mechanics and challenges that keep the experience fresh and compelling, all while maintaining a seamless flow.

The controls are intuitive, allowing you to focus on the atmospheric immersion rather than struggling with clunky mechanics. The puzzles are cleverly designed, requiring a mix of logic and timing, and the sense of tension is ever-present. The minimalist design of the game ensures that every element‚Äîfrom the ominous soundtrack to the eerie sound effects‚Äîserves to enhance the overall mood and narrative.

Aesthetic Brilliance:
One of the standout features of Inside is its aesthetic design. The game‚Äôs visual style is both striking and understated. The use of muted colors and shadowy environments creates a sense of foreboding and mystery that perfectly complements the narrative. The detailed and atmospheric backgrounds, combined with the fluid animation of the protagonist, result in a visually stunning experience that remains memorable.

The game‚Äôs environments are meticulously crafted, with each area offering a unique and unsettling atmosphere. The seamless transitions between different settings‚Äîfrom industrial complexes to eerie underwater sections‚Äîdemonstrate the developers‚Äô keen eye for detail and artistic vision. Inside‚Äôs ability to convey so much with so little is a testament to its aesthetic mastery.

Nostalgia and Impact:
Playing Inside when I was younger was a deeply immersive experience. The game‚Äôs haunting atmosphere and enigmatic storytelling left a significant mark, creating memories that have stayed with me. Returning to it now, the nostalgia is palpable. The sense of wonder and unease that accompanied my first playthrough is rekindled, reminding me of why Inside remains such a standout title in my gaming history.

The emotional impact of the game, combined with its visual and auditory brilliance, ensures that it remains a powerful and evocative experience. It‚Äôs a game that continues to resonate, proving that even years later, its artistic and narrative qualities hold up exceptionally well.

Final Thoughts:
Inside is more than just a game; it‚Äôs an evocative journey through a meticulously crafted world. Its aesthetic brilliance and haunting atmosphere make it a standout title that continues to captivate and intrigue. The nostalgia of playing it in my younger years, combined with the timeless quality of its design, makes it a memorable and cherished part of my gaming history.

For anyone who appreciates games that push the boundaries of storytelling and visual design, Inside is an experience that should not be missed. Its ability to evoke strong emotions and leave a lasting impression is a testament to its enduring impact and artistic achievement.

I saw we call a general strike until Playdead release a new game. It's been too long.

Look, I'm a middle-aged guy who has been a lapsed gamer for over 20 years now. And obviously a lot has happened in video gaming in that time, so please forgive me for being so hyperbolic about the beauty and darkness of Inside, which may or may not have been matched by other games. This game though, is easily one of the greatest things I've ever played and I find its use of backgrounds in the gameplay to be perhaps its strongest feature.

I might even love it more than Limbo.

It's like that quirky friend who shows up at your party wearing mismatched socks and a neon beanie. It defies conventions, laughs in the face of predictability, and dances to its own glitchy soundtrack. Buckle up, because this game takes you on a wild ride through a digital dreamscape.

üåü Graphics and Aesthetics: Imagine Salvador Dal√≠ and H.R. Giger collaborating on a pixel art project. The visuals are a kaleidoscope of surreal landscapes, glitchy creatures, and mind-bending puzzles. It‚Äôs like your screen dropped acid and decided to trip out.

üéµ Soundtrack: The music? Oh, it‚Äôs not just a soundtrack; it‚Äôs an auditory wormhole. Synths collide with glitchy beats, creating an otherworldly vibe. You‚Äôll find yourself humming these tunes while waiting in line at the grocery store. Trust me.

üß† Gameplay: Puzzles? More like brain acrobatics. ‚ÄúInside the Game‚Äù doesn‚Äôt hold your hand; it tickles your neurons. You‚Äôll manipulate time, gravity, and existential dread. Just when you think you‚Äôve cracked it, the game smirks and throws a curveball. It‚Äôs like playing chess with an AI that quotes Nietzsche.

ü§ñ Characters: Meet our protagonist, Pixel Pete. He‚Äôs a glitchy hero with commitment issues. His sidekick? A sentient toaster named Crispy. Together, they battle existential bugs and unravel the game‚Äôs cryptic narrative. Think ‚ÄúThe Matrix‚Äù meets ‚ÄúAlice in Wonderland.‚Äù

üåà Overall Vibe: ‚ÄúInside the Game‚Äù isn‚Äôt just a game; it‚Äôs a glitchy love letter to the absurd. It winks at reality, flirts with chaos theory, and whispers, ‚ÄúHey, player, reality is overrated.‚Äù So grab your joystick, sip your digital coffee, and dive into this pixelated rabbit hole. You‚Äôll emerge equal parts enlightened and bewildered.

üéÆ Rating: 9/10 (Lost a point because Pixel Pete still owes me 20 virtual bucks.)

"Inside," developed by Playdead, is a hauntingly atmospheric puzzle-platformer set in a dark, dystopian world. Through its minimalist storytelling and meticulously crafted scenery, the game conveys profound themes of control and freedom without a single word. Each environment is rich with detail, enhancing immersion and adding depth to the silent, tense narrative. "Inside" is a masterclass in visual and interactive storytelling, making it a must-play for enthusiasts of thoughtful, narrative-driven games.
One of my favourite games of all time. A timeless masterpiece.

This review is based on 100% completion and 3.1 hours of gameplay.

[h1][b]Recommendation:[/b][/h1]
Would I recommend this game? Yes, it was an interesting experience. Do I understand what is actually going on with the story they are trying to tell? Nope. Was it still very interesting and intriguing? Absolutely. This game gives off strong ‚ÄúLittle Nightmares‚Äù vibes, so if you enjoyed those games, there's a good chance you'll have a great experience with this one.

I went into this semi-blind, and while I have absolutely no idea what the story that the developers are trying to tell here is, you can make some educated assumptions, which I think adds to the charm of the game. It doesn‚Äôt tell you what to do or explicitly how to think‚Äîyou figure things out yourself. When you boot up the game, it drops you straight in‚Äîno title screen, no tutorial, no hand-holding. I'm a bit torn on how to feel about that, but it‚Äôs okay.

The progression is done really well and feels fluid. The environment looks very nice, and the art style is a good choice for this game. The clever use of lighting and colours to guide the player is done very well, and the sound design is nice, complementing the other elements of the game to create a really interesting and tense atmosphere.

The actual gameplay aspect worked very well for me and was fluid. Everything did what I expected it to, and I didn‚Äôt run into any bugs or issues. The puzzle-solving is easy and intuitive, so you won‚Äôt get stuck and if you do it won‚Äôt be for long, which is nice. It's not so easy that it becomes boring, which is good. The deaths are really interesting, and I wasn't expecting some of them to be so brutal‚Äîa pleasant surprise. Even though you may die a lot, the game is very forgiving with its saves/respawns, so you‚Äôll be right next to where you failed, which is really nice.

Overall, I had a pleasant experience with this game and would love to explore the lore more later on. While I enjoyed this, I do not recommend buying this game at the base price‚ÄîI don‚Äôt think the content-to-price ratio is worth it. The game has regular sales, so finding a good deal shouldn‚Äôt be too difficult if you can wait. While on sale this is a good pick up.

[h1][b]Achievement:[/b][/h1]
All the achievements in this game are tied to finding the disco-looking orbs throughout the game. There‚Äôs a good guide by ‚ÄúBrachragon‚Äù in the Steam guides [url= https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2147616108] here. [/url] There are no story spoilers, and the guide includes pictures, making it very easy to follow. I recommend following the guide so you can do everything in a single playthrough.

There are no missable achievements in this game, thanks to the chapter select option in the pause menu. So, if you want to find them all yourself or you miss some, it‚Äôs not too difficult to go back. This is a very easy 100%.

I tried Limbo because it had very high scores, but after playing for 2 hours, I didn't like it and stopped. Then, I saw a recommendation on Steam to play Inside by the Limbo developers due to its high scores. Inside boasts an overwhelmingly high score of 96% on Steam, along with a 93/8.3 rating on Metacritic, and it has received numerous awards, including BAFTA and TGA. So I forced myself to play for over 3 hours, nearly finishing the game before deciding to stop. I don‚Äôt believe that so many people on Steam and Metacritic could be wrong, yet I absolutely didn‚Äôt enjoy the game. Here‚Äôs why:

[h3] Scenario 3/10 [/h3]

The game immediately grabs your interest as you control a boy who jumps down and runs through dangerous, mystic enemies and locations, delving deeper into the dark and mysterious depths of what seems like a dystopian base/city/laboratory. You find yourself asking, "What is going on?", "Who is this boy?", and "Why is he doing this?" Unfortunately, you won‚Äôt find any answers, nor will you receive any adequate clues about what is happening. The lack of dialogue, characters, text, or speech means you're left to piece together the plot yourself, which begs the question: what‚Äôs the point of playing if you must invent the story? I give 3 points for the beginning, but 0 for both the middle and the ending.

[h3] Visuals 8/10 [/h3]

The visuals are minimalistic, stylish, and atmospheric, which I must admit is the game's strongest aspect. The camera movements, colors, and locations are all executed brilliantly, creating an intriguing spectacle of dark energy smeared across the screen. Although some areas and units are repetitive, the art team has done an impressive job overall.

[h3] Sound design 4/10 [/h3]

The game features almost no music, only offering a few brief moments of sound. You spend most of the game listening to footsteps and the sounds of actions and enemies around you. On one hand, this silence enhances the atmosphere, evoking a sense of loneliness and decay. However, on the other hand, it exacerbates the boredom when you're simply running through empty corridors, making the experience even more tedious.

[h3] Gameplay 3/10 [/h3]

Despite being categorized as a puzzle platformer on Steam, the 'platformer' aspect is sparse, with most of the game involving running forward and solving overly simplistic puzzles. There are some moderately difficult puzzles, but their challenge stems only from the unfamiliarity with the objects involved, rather than from inherent puzzle complexity.

[h3] Overall 4/10 [/h3]

Inside is an interesting example of a unique visual and narrative style. If you are curious about exploring different aesthetics in games, it‚Äôs worth a look. However, if you're seeking challenging puzzles, engaging gameplay, and a compelling plot‚Äîas most players do‚ÄîI cannot recommend this game.

Inside is a dystopian game following the main character: a small child navigating their world alone. But they aren't alone for long. With a sinister lab full of technicians and their experiments the child must solve puzzles to continue their journey to uncovering the truth of what lies beneath or rather...what lies inside. 

I truly enjoyed the attention to detail in this game. The 2 dimensional feel of movement resembles the play style of "Limbo" and "Little Nightmares". The graphics are beautifully though out. The soundtrack is both eerie and captivating. 

The puzzles throughout increase in difficulty but are stimulating and fun! 

For a smaller game I can tell a lot of love and labor went into its development. I 100% recommend this game for puzzle lovers!

Inside looked good and is kind of what you'd expect to see in a LIMBO sequel, but in 3D. And the visuals and locations seem to be fairly decent as well as the characters, but the game just left me wanting more. I expected there to be more to the story like LIMBO, where there was some purpose to the adventure, but instead the game was way longer than LIMBO and the puzzles were more complex, yet after all the trouble of getting to the end I never got a chance to understand the "why" of this game. The story just ends abruptly and then repeats with no ending cutscene and the collectibles are near impossible to find on some occasions without a guide. And even then, there is no meaning behind these, they're kind of just "there". Also the underwater levels really affect the game's pacing as well as the swimming ones, because they really make the game more confusing and lengthy while not being very fun or creative. They're kind of just in the way. It wasn't the worst to grab on sale, but I certainly enjoyed LIMBO more.

After having played through the game to 100% completion, reading up on all the ARG details and watching countless videos about the story... I still don't have a clue what this is all about.

But that doesn't mean it's bad. Far from it. INSIDE is great, with a beautiful artsyle, intriguing (if somewhat vague) story, and puzzles that hit that sweet spot of "not too easy to switch your brain off, not too hard to rage-quit" (and some interesting secrets for you to go back and look for). 

For people looking for games with a strong, immersive atmosphere and unique experience, INSIDE is must-have. And for everyone else, it's definitely still worth considering.

game director arnt jensen ka kehna hai inside game ko banane ke liye kuch extra funding unhe danish film institute se mila.

san 2014 ki e3 event ke dwaran inside game ka ek premiere hua tha par 2015 ki jagah 2016 ko mukti mili..

yeh jo 1 saal ki delay hui iska reason hai ki playdead is game ko baki consoles jaise ki playstation aur mac pe vi port karna chahta tha.

waise 2016 ki e3 ke dwaran hi playdead ne final release date ki pusti kar di thi aur lage hato apni pehli game title limbo ke bohot sare copies free mein baat diya..

for marketing purpose.

aur akhir kar ki 29th june 2016 ko yeh game release hua

Anyways, inside game adat mein puzzle platformer limbo jaisa hi hai par yaha chize thodi boht saturated hai...

chaliye baat karte hai.

ek tanao-purn dystopian settings mein aap is game ko experience karoge....

dystopia matlab ek aisa samaj jaha injustice vari padi ho aur log jaha suffer karta hai

kher, in game world apko ek dark mahol create karke dega aur semi post apocalyptic ek ehsaas apko zaroor milega game ko khelte huye..

in game protagonist ka koi naam nehi hai par adat mein yeh ek fearless teeneger hi hai

Gameplay

game ko khelte hi aap direct gameplay stage mein poch jaoge..

aur bina koi rukawat ya distruction ke aap mahol ko enjoy karte huye agey badoge..

mujhe kafi pasand hai yeh approach because straight to gameplay ka yeh mechanics players ko wait nehi karwata.

waise wapas kabivi aap in game basic settings mein changes kar sakte ho waise controller ka istemal kar paoge...lekin yeh game button smasher bilkul vi nhi h

ultrawide angle support karta hai aur chaho toh brightness ko vi bada sakte ho.

ek dehsat se vara unknown world ki yeh journey apko side scrolling ke madhyam se karni hogi..

yes its a side scroller title just like limbo.

apki character waise toh harmless hoga in nature par bade sare twists aap experience karoge as you progress in the game...

waise puzzles apko zaroor milenge...yeh puzzles waise limbo game ki tarah frequent nehi hoga...par environmental hoga in nature.

agar puri gameplay time ki baat kare toh kayi sare puzzling mujhe reused laga..

in game dhero machineries apko dikhenge...robotic atmosphere milega..

har mod mein apko kayi sare swal man mein ayega ...aur kuch dur chalte hi jawab vi apko milne lagega..

storytelling thoda had tak confusing lagega apko specially in initial phases.

dekhiye playdead ke developers apne game mein trial and death mechanism ke upar zor dete hai..

aur iske chalte apki character kayi bar marega..

aur alag alag variation se aaa haha pki mrityu ho sakti hai

waise maroge vi toh wapas recent checkpoint se suru kar sakoge.. jo ki apko jyada se jyada 1 - 2 minute piche le jayega apki current position se.

agar main limbo se compare karu toh deaths ke mawamle mein inside game is less forgiving than its predecessor limbo.

waise toh aap combat nehi kar sakte...main idea hai apko bas agey badte rehna..iske chalte traps ko avoid karo..puzzle ko solve karo...bas you are all good..

parkour wise yeh game mein apko basic sa approach milega.

you can run jump push pull objects..swim vi kar loge..aur darkar pade toh swing vi..

aap waise ek machine ko apne dimag ke istemal se kaam mein la sakte ho...

jiske badolat kuch robotic entities ko aap apne hisab se kaam karwa paoge..

yeh wala chiz mujhe badiya laga..

in game total 67 padao milenge...aap chapters vi kehlo ise koi isses nehi hai par jabivi aap gameplay ko experiece karoge yeh apke liye distraction nehi banega..

aur nahi koi cutscenes hoga game mein..

in game kuch secret items hoga jisse aap light orbs se janoge..total 14 aise light orbs milega..

waise inside game ki secret ending vi yehi orbs ke sath judi huyi hai.

Graphics..

unity engine ke upar bani inside game apni predecessor limbo se thoda had tak advanced hai..

yaha apko colors dekhneko milenge..

fir vi jyadatar gameplay nighttime mein ek gloomy atmosphere ko hi experience karwayega apko

aise settings mein environemtal lighting ka purjor support chahiye hota hai..

jo ki mila vi developers ke taraf se..

kuch section ko chod inside game mein ek behetareen world art ka muzaira ki gyi hai..

takriban 12 dark spooky sound tracks ke sath nirmit inside game ko score kiya hai

Martin Stig Andersen - jinhone khud limbo game ko vi compose kiya tha..

is game ka sound effects gameplay ke sath kafi had tak juda hua hai..

jaise ki some puzzles set directly to visual-aural cues. 

gameplay ka jyadatar hissa silent hi hai par kuch kuch jaga horror ambient music dali gyi hai..

iske ilawa in game mechinaries ke sound...kutte ka bhokna ..yeh toh rahega hi

waise 3 se lekar 5 ghante mein aap is single player game title ko apne pc xbos ps nintendo ya mac mein enjoy kar sakoge.

pc ke system requirements yeh raha apke screen ke upar.

Outro

Dystopian world mein apki journey romanch se Vara hua rahega.. puzzles ..traps.. finding orbs.. everything is fine but kahi na kahi game apko ek badiya storytelling se benchit rakha..

Sayad cutscene ki zaroorat thi..sayad dialogue ki..

Lekin limbo game ka sequel hone ke nate wohi purani pattern ko barkarar rakha gya

Wohi abrupt ending apko Chand sawalo ke sath chodega..

All in all.. it's a fun play..5 hours we'll spend.. par sayad yeh game ka replaybility bohot hi kaam logo ko attract kare.

"Inside," developed by Playdead, is a hauntingly beautiful puzzle-platformer that delivers an unforgettable gaming experience. This atmospheric game captures your attention from the very beginning with its strikingly minimalist art style and captivating sound design.

The game follows a young boy navigating through a dark, dystopian world filled with mystery and danger. The visual storytelling is masterful, using light, shadow, and color to convey emotion and narrative without a single word of dialogue. Each scene is meticulously crafted, immersing players in a bleak yet mesmerizing environment.

Gameplay is a seamless blend of platforming and puzzle-solving. The controls are tight and responsive, and the puzzles are cleverly designed, challenging players to think creatively without ever feeling unfair. The sense of progression is perfectly paced, with each new area introducing fresh mechanics and challenges that keep the experience engaging from start to finish.

"Inside" excels in creating a sense of tension and suspense, thanks to its eerie atmosphere and hauntingly beautiful soundtrack. The sound design enhances the experience, with every footstep, creak, and ambient noise adding to the overall sense of unease.

In summary, "Inside" is a short but impactful game that leaves a lasting impression. Its stunning visuals, atmospheric storytelling, and engaging gameplay make it a must-play for fans of puzzle-platformers and anyone looking for a deeply immersive gaming experience.

How can you not love Inside? A top contender at The Game Awards 2016, this game is a masterpiece. Even though it's short (I finished it in about 3 hours), every moment is packed with incredible qualities. The immersive atmosphere and subtle narrative are captivating.

Warning: Inside is not for those seeking traditional challenges. With no clear instructions, the game requires you to think and reason on your own. There were times I was completely stuck and had to turn to YouTube for help.

For those who are deaf, don't worry. The game has no crucial dialogues. You can play it muted but I recommend keeping the sound on - the soundtrack is simply fantastic.

Inside is an unforgettable adventure that challenges the mind and touches the soul.
An aesthetic masterpiece.

‚ÄúInside‚Äù isn‚Äôt just a game; it‚Äôs an enigma wrapped in shadows and silence. Developed by Playdead, this atmospheric puzzle-platformer invites you to step into a world where questions outnumber answers.

Every frame in ‚ÄúInside‚Äù feels like a brushstroke on a canvas of despair. The monochromatic palette, punctuated by vivid reds, sets an eerie tone.
The attention to detail is staggering. Dust motes dance in shafts of light, and raindrops ripple in murky pools. It‚Äôs a visual symphony.
Prepare for stark contrasts‚Äîdarkness against light, life against decay. The world breathes, and you‚Äôre a silent witness.
Mechanically, it‚Äôs a 2D platformer, but that‚Äôs merely the surface. There are no tutorials, no hand-holding. You‚Äôre thrown into the abyss.
Puzzles emerge organically from the environment. Physics, timing, and intuition guide you. Each solution feels like a revelation.
The narrative unfolds wordlessly. You‚Äôll question motives, unravel secrets, and wonder what lies beyond the next door.
‚ÄúInside‚Äù doesn‚Äôt explain; it evokes. Fear, wonder, and melancholy intertwine. The boy‚Äôs journey becomes your own.
Moments of horror and beauty collide. You‚Äôll feel a knot in your chest, a shiver down your spine. It‚Äôs hauntingly intimate.
The brevity (about three hours) amplifies the emotional punch. It‚Äôs like a fleeting dream‚Äîone you‚Äôll remember forever.

Conclusion
‚ÄúInside‚Äù defies categorization. It‚Äôs a cryptic poem, a silent scream, a dance with shadows. Play it. Discuss it. Let it seep into your soul.

WARNING: Spoilers in this review, read at your own risk

This game is well designed and very creative. The graphics are great, and the game does a fantastic job at setting the mood of suspense and exploration. It is too short-lived, but it is nonetheless overall entertaining. 

However the reason I give this game a thumbs down is that for all its good, it disappoints at the end. The story is fairly consistent until a key point in the game where you begin having a modified ability. This in and of itself isn't that off par with the storyline, but suddenly toward the end things get very weird and very fast. It seems from this development that something very climactic is going to happen, yet the end results in you simply rolling out of a wall and dying - with a tediously slow zoom out before the credits. 

No explanation, no climax, nothing meaningful. Just a story that was good and suddenly got weird and cuts off abruptly. 

Also the secrets in this game are fun to find, but their reward is very poor. It takes a good bit of work to unlock the secret, and it is also incredibly un-climactic. You are in a room, pull out a plug and the room goes dark. And that's it. What? After all that work? No extra area to explore? No alternate journey? Nothing? Very disappointing.

[b] Inside: A Haunting and Atmospheric Masterpiece [/b]

'Inside' is a haunting and atmospheric platformer that takes players on a dark and enigmatic journey. Developed by Playdead, the creators of the critically acclaimed 'Limbo,' 'Inside' is a testament to the studio's ability to create compelling and emotionally impactful experiences.

[b] Unveiling a Dystopian Nightmare [/b]

The game follows an anonymous boy who finds himself in a twisted and oppressive world. Players are thrust into a grayscale landscape filled with monstrous creatures, looming structures, and unsettling environments. The game's subtle and minimalist visuals create a palpable sense of unease and dread.

[b] Gripping Gameplay with Emotional Resonance [/b]

'Inside' combines platforming gameplay with puzzle elements that challenge players' wits and reflexes. The controls are simple yet precise, allowing for fluid and immersive movement. Each level presents unique challenges, ranging from navigating treacherous traps to avoiding grotesque enemies.

What sets 'Inside' apart is its ability to evoke profound emotions. The game's horrific imagery and unsettling encounters leave a lasting impression on players. The boy's journey becomes a metaphor for our own fears and vulnerabilities, reminding us of the fragility of life and the darkness that lurks within.

[b] Masterful Sound Design [/b]

The game's sound design is a masterpiece in its own right. Ambient sounds and minimalist music create an eerie and oppressive atmosphere. Every creak, whisper, and heartbeat amplifies the tension and immerses players in the game's unsettling world.

[b] An Unforgettable Experience [/b]

'Inside' is not a game for the faint of heart. It is a challenging, thought-provoking, and ultimately unforgettable experience. Its haunting visuals, gripping gameplay, and emotionally resonant narrative create a masterpiece that will stay with players long after they finish it.

[b] Pros: [/b]

* Haunting and atmospheric visuals
* Gripping gameplay that combines platforming and puzzles
* Profound and emotionally evocative narrative
* Masterful sound design

[b] Cons: [/b]

* May be too intense for some players
* Lack of explicit storytelling may leave some players confused

ehhhhhhhh....... it's alright. Not for me. 

The game is visually stunning. The sound design was also very good. The themeing was also very nice. That's all this game seems to do for me, however. Despite the atmosphere or themeing being well executed to such a high degree, I often found myself bored, frustrated and confused. There are some neat mechanics, but the puzzles would either be too linear and simple or very open and confusing. And the rest of the gameplay is either running or swimming. The protagonist is not even super fun to control, and is kind of slow. And also, there is SO MUCH SWIMMING! Why? I don't really mind swimming in video games but there is an unnecessary amount of swimming to be done. The only 'side content' this game has to offer are these secret capsule thingies you can find if you explore. There are not that many of these, and based off the ones that I could find, they are either very simple and easy to find or they are incredibly obscure. 

The story is supposedly one of the main parts of this game but it is so open-ended that I could not find much interest in it. It starts out interesting, but then the puzzles and filler start to take over with only little hints of the story sprinkled into certain areas. Then towards the second half of the game the narrative starts to kick in again but this time it starts getting confusing, up until the final act and it ends in a very anti-climactic fashion. The ending makes no sense to me? And there is so little context and background information to theorise anything about it. And what I mean about "filler", I mean that there is a lot of travelling in random places, such as overgrown areas or mine shafts or flooded buildings? I am so confused on why we are travelling through these places other than to end up in the final area, which very conveniently happens to be at the end of all that traversing. And the protagonist? Why does he think travelling through such places will work out in the end? Why are we even going to where we are going? How does he know where to... go? And if he doesn't, why are we ending up in such convenient places to meet up with the bad guys? The final act is also... a thing that happens. All the shenanigans that happen in the final act is not explained and is so confusing. Why is everything so damn confusing?!

Overall the game is still well-made. There is clearly a lot of effort that was put into the game, and it offered a neat experience. However based on what I've said above, there is a lot this game does not do well to me. This game is not worth its full price, but this game seems to be going on a lot of big sales so you can try it out and see for yourself.

Atmospheric Brilliance with Unrivaled Gameplay

Inside, from the creators of Limbo, is an atmospheric masterpiece that sets a new benchmark in the indie game scene. The game thrusts players into a hauntingly beautiful yet eerily oppressive world, where every shadow hides a secret and each silence tells a story.

Graphics and Sound Design: 10/10

From the moment you step into the world of Inside, you're enveloped in a meticulously crafted environment. The game employs a minimalist yet highly detailed art style that accentuates the bleakness of its dystopian setting. The use of light and shadow is nothing short of masterful, creating a sense of depth and tension that few games can match.

Complementing the visuals is the sound design, which is equally impressive. The absence of a traditional soundtrack heightens the impact of environmental sounds‚Äîcreaking doors, distant machinery, and the protagonist's footsteps become key elements of the narrative. This auditory experience is crucial in building the game's suspenseful atmosphere.

Gameplay Mechanics: 9/10

Inside excels in delivering a seamless and intuitive gameplay experience. The controls are straightforward, yet the puzzles are anything but simplistic. Each challenge is organically integrated into the environment, requiring players to think creatively and interact with their surroundings in innovative ways. The game's pacing is impeccable, gradually increasing in complexity without ever becoming frustratingly difficult.

One of the standout features is the fluidity of the protagonist's movements. The animations are smooth and realistic, adding to the immersion and making every action feel consequential. Whether you're sneaking past guards, navigating treacherous terrain, or solving intricate puzzles, the game maintains a relentless grip on your attention.

Narrative and Atmosphere: 10/10

The narrative of Inside is conveyed through its world rather than traditional storytelling methods. There is no dialogue or text to guide you; instead, the game relies on environmental storytelling to weave its enigmatic tale. This approach encourages players to piece together the story through observation and interpretation, leading to a deeply personal and engaging experience.

The atmosphere is where Inside truly shines. The game's world is both beautiful and disturbing, filled with haunting imagery and unsettling scenarios. The sense of isolation and vulnerability is palpable, creating a constant undercurrent of tension. Every element, from the subdued color palette to the meticulously designed soundscape, contributes to this immersive experience.

Conclusion:

Inside is a triumph of atmospheric gameplay, offering a richly crafted world that draws players in and refuses to let go. Its blend of stunning visuals, masterful sound design, and intelligent puzzle mechanics make it a standout title in the indie gaming landscape. For those seeking a game that challenges the mind while captivating the senses, Inside is an absolute must-play.

Overall Score: 9.5/10

WOW. Playdead's Inside is one of those games that after the credits roll you just sit there in silence. In fact, throughout this entire game I was in silence. Inside instantly grabbed my attention, and kept me hook the entire time. I'm struggling to find anything wrong with the game. It's genuinely perfect, and already consider it to be among my top gaming experiences. 

Obviously the games strongest pro is the sound design and ambience. It's definitely some of the best sound design in any game I've ever played. The chilling images that foreshadow what is to proceed is done expertly, and has some of the best use of a flat art style I've seen. The way the camera works is amazing and loved the wide shots that would make you look insanely small. How the story reveals its self is great due to the perfect pacing of the game. Inside introduces new mechanics just before the previous ones get old. Seriously I don't think I've seen better pacing since I first played Half-Life 2. Another part of the excellent pacing is the puzzles, which are beyond creative. I love how majority of the puzzles happen when your in danger, which adds a new level of intensity making the puzzles engaging. The constant close calls are what really set the present danger, and cause genuine fear.

 The ending was unexpected, and I thought by the end the game revealed just the right amount information, to open room for theories. The way I interpret it is like most but I have a few things I add that might be different. For the sake of spoilers I won't say anything. There is so much more I can say in detail. However, it would ruin the magic. You just have to play it for yourself, so you can see the brilliance of Playdead's Inside.

Visuals? Holy moly, they were out of this world! The art style was like a perfect blend of dark and captivating. It sucked me right into its surreal universe, where every frame felt meticulously crafted. Seriously, it was like a feast for the eyes, and I couldn't look away!

Let's talk puzzles, shall we? Inside knows how to challenge your brain cells. These puzzles were no joke, my friends. They required some serious out-of-the-box thinking and problem-solving skills. It was like the developers were playing a game of "how to drive players insane with mind-bending challenges." But hey, that's what made it so damn satisfying when you finally cracked those brain-busters!

Now, the story. Oh boy, the story! Inside had this enigmatic vibe that kept me hooked from start to finish. It was like an interactive mystery novel where you're left to unravel the secrets of this bizarre world all on your own. The lack of explicit explanations only added to the intrigue. Trust me, you'll be left with more questions than answers, and that's part of the magic!

Sound design? A+. The audio team nailed it! The atmospheric sounds and haunting music created an immersive experience that sent shivers down my spine. It was like being trapped in a suspenseful thriller, where every creak and whisper heightened the tension. Major props to the sound wizards behind this masterpiece!

Now, let's address the length. Inside may not be the longest game out there, but it's all about quality over quantity, my friends. The developers knew how to make every minute count. The pacing was spot-on, keeping the intensity high and the momentum rolling. Plus, the replayability factor with hidden secrets and alternate paths adds extra value and extends the enjoyment.

In conclusion, if you're a gamer seeking an unforgettable journey, Inside is a must-play. The mind-blowing visuals, brain-teasing puzzles, mysterious narrative, and immersive sound design combine to create an epic gaming experience.

Inside is a hauntingly beautiful masterpiece that defies conventional gaming norms to deliver an unforgettable experience. Developed by Playdead, the creators of Limbo, this game takes players on a journey through a surreal and dystopian world where every moment is filled with tension and intrigue.

Similar to Limbo, game-play in Inside is minimalist yet incredibly immersive. Players control a young boy navigating through a series of puzzles and obstacles, all while uncovering the dark secrets of the world around him. The puzzles are cleverly designed, often requiring a blend of logical thinking and precise timing. The simplicity of controls enhances the experience, allowing the focus to remain on the unfolding narrative and atmospheric tension.

****Spoiler alert for those who haven't played Inside.

The conclusion of Inside is deliberately enigmatic and open to interpretation, leaving players with more questions than concrete answers. As the game progresses, players guide the protagonist through increasingly surreal and ominous environments, encountering strange experiments and mind-control devices along the way. The ultimate goal seems to be breaking free from this oppressive world.

In the climactic final sequence, the boy (controlled by the player) reaches the heart of a facility where a massive blob-like creature is suspended. By using mind-control helmets, the player commands a horde of mindless humanoids to connect to the blob, forming a grotesque human chain. The boy, instead of joining this chain, disconnects the blob from its life-support system, causing it to burst through the facility and roll downhill, ultimately crashing into a body of water.

The boy seemingly merges with the blob, gaining control of its abilities. The game then continues with the boy now in control of the blob, able to breathe underwater and swim away. This ending implies a form of rebirth or transformation, suggesting that the protagonist has transcended the constraints of his former existence.

While the alternate ending, after collecting all the orbs, show a hidden mind control switch. Upon activating the switch, the boy collapses to the ground, motionless. The screen fades to black, leaving players to ponder the implications of this unexpected turn of events. This ending adds a layer of intrigue and mystery to the game's narrative, raising questions about the nature of the boy, the purpose of the mind-control devices, and the true intentions of the game's antagonistic forces. 

In conclusion, Inside is a must-play for anyone seeking a thought-provoking and visually striking gaming experience. It challenges the boundaries of storytelling in gaming and leaves a lasting impression that few games can match. Whether you're a fan of puzzle-platformers or narrative-driven games, Inside offers an unforgettable journey into the unknown.

MASTERPIECE ‚Äî no other word suffices to describe this game. Experiencing it has been an absolute delight. From the physical effects and sound design to the camera work in the 2.5D scenes and the masterful control of the player's emotions, every aspect is executed with high proficiency. The hints provided through lighting and camera movements strike the perfect balance, guiding without overwhelming. The mechanical equipment is designed with both realism and functionality in mind, impressively so. It's astonishing how a variety of puzzles have been ingeniously crafted using just a few basic modules. The characters evoke empathy.
Complete the game in 5.5 hours, unlocking 5/14 achievements. Rumor has it that there's a better ending awaiting those who earn all the achievements, so I'm definitely going to achieve that.

An even more surreal, immersive, improved piece of masterwork from Playdead...I might argue it's even better than Limbo! Playing this in the dark with some good headphones is an experience to be remembered. Love the ambience, graphics, lighting, sound design (golly), and of course all the world building and what-the-actual-frick sense of all that is happening/happened as you explore the facilities...hot diggity dog!

"Inside" is a masterful piece of interactive storytelling and atmospheric puzzle-platforming. Developed by Playdead, the creators of "Limbo," this game takes players on a haunting journey through a dystopian world filled with mystery and danger.

One of the game's most striking features is its visual design. The art direction is impeccable, using a muted color palette and minimalist style to create a sense of foreboding and intrigue. Every scene is meticulously crafted, with detailed backgrounds and fluid animations that enhance the immersive experience.

The gameplay of "Inside" is both challenging and rewarding. The puzzles are cleverly designed, requiring players to think critically and experiment with their environment. The controls are intuitive and responsive, making the platforming segments feel smooth and satisfying. As you progress, the game introduces new mechanics and obstacles that keep the experience fresh and engaging.

The narrative of "Inside" is subtle yet powerful. Without a single line of dialogue, the game tells a compelling story through its environments, character actions, and eerie atmosphere. This approach allows players to interpret the story in their own way, adding to the game's depth and replayability.

The sound design and musical score further enhance the game's unsettling mood. The sparse use of sound effects and ambient noise creates an oppressive atmosphere, while the music underscores the tension and mystery of the world.

"Inside" is a short but unforgettable experience that leaves a lasting impact. Its combination of striking visuals, engaging gameplay, and thought-provoking storytelling makes it a standout title in the indie game scene. Playdead has crafted a game that is as beautiful as it is haunting, and it is a must-play for fans of atmospheric and narrative-driven games.

Inside is a perfect example of developers taking a beautifully executed concept like Limbo and elevating it in simple and extremely effective ways. 

I am not sure if it was because I was already familiar with the game mechanics of Limbo that Inside's puzzles felt easier, but I wouldn't necessary say that's a bad thing. I never felt frustrated with Inside the way I felt with Limbo at times. Instead I was able to focus more on the atmosphere and art/sound design that was beautiful and haunting.  There's something surreal about being dropped right in the middle of a story and enjoying how they peel back layer after layer of the world around you.

I am incredibly glad I was never spoiled for the ending of this game. I could see how some people might find it divisive, but I personally love games that allow room for interpretation as a creative art piece. I'm definitely here for whatever Playdead has up their sleeves in the future.

Some games don't hit, and that's probably my case with INSIDE. I had a better time playing LIMBO for sure.

The atmosphere, storytelling and visuals were nice... In the first two thirds. After that, it's all the same industrial-scientific-lab and the worst thing by far is the [b] HUGE AMONT OF WATER SEQUENCES [/b]. I swear, it became so often that whenever the game pushes me to take a swim i was like [i] "For fuck's sacke dude, really? AGAIN?" [/i]. I usually don't have problems with "Water levels" on games, and INSIDE, when dosed, have some really good and interesting mechanics exploring them, but theres A LOT of swimming simulator too.

About the puzzles. They were much easier than in LIMBO, but that's not really a issue for my. I found INSIDE [u] lacking specially [/u] in puzzles, with always more or less the same mechanics and they took longer to physically execute than it did to mentally solve. It usually was consisting of a 3 part puzzle, activating something, going back to activate something else and then finally going back again to activate something else and proceed. Or scenarios like this: there is a part where some hounds are chasing you, and you have climb back and forth over the same fence multiple times to escape.

Like i said, about completing ~60% of the game, i got bored. I was anxious to see a different scenario besides the gray industral complex or polluted water. Or some actual development in the story. I know, LIMBO follow the same pattern: scenarios don't drastically change and you don't get any clue until the end. The difference is, there's more memorable moments, puzzles and enemies in LIMBO. Here, the only "outstanding" thing is the mermaid or whatever the fuck is that copy of the girl from The Ring and all the mind control / evil lab backstory. About the ending i don't have much to say, because i already expected something vague coming from Playdead and that's cool.

Inside. A game that unravels the darkest corridors of the human psyche, much like exploring the depths of one's soul. The creators of "Limbo" have crafted a masterful narrative, woven with eerie silence and oppressive atmosphere, pulling you deeper into a hauntingly beautiful world. The protagonist's journey, shrouded in mystery, resonates with a profound sense of inevitability and existential dread. The puzzles are not mere obstacles but reflections of the intricate and often sinister machinations of the world around us.

Inside is an experience, not just a game. It captures the essence of what it means to be alone in a world that is as captivating as it is terrifying. Every step taken, every shadow encountered, brings a sense of dread and fascination that is hard to escape. It is a chilling reminder of the darkness that can reside within and the external forces that shape our existence.

In its bleak and somber narrative, Inside finds beauty, much like the complexities of the human condition. It is a journey worth taking, for it lingers in the mind long after the final scene fades. Truly, another masterpiece from same authors and develeopers which I cannot say any negatives or minuses.
One of the most unique, and best, games I've ever played. It's a piece of art, and a wild ride. Don't look anything up.

Let me tell you what a little gem this is! :-) A ray of hope received for the gaming "industry" now dominated by multi billion dollar corporate monster machines.
A truly memorable journey that lingers and stays with you for a while. The graphic design is beautifully minimal and reminds me so much of Limbo, but in colour...I think you could notice some of the elements and inspiration drawn from the legendary Another World too. In a nutshell you could sum it up as a classic "2.5D puzzle platformer" with a mysterious storytelling and outstanding, stylised visuals.
[h3]What's good:[/h3]
[list]
[*] beautiful visual style and sound design
[*] masterful storytelling (but I guess it might not work well for some as nothing really gets explained here - so [b]if you look for answers, please note that you will find NONE[/b])
[*] puzzles which are prefectly and seamlessly integreated into the gameplay and story
[/list]
[h3]What's bad:[/h3]
[list]
[*] I really can't think of anything in particular here. You might say that this is not an extensive game that can be finished in one sitting... The 6.2 hrs of playtine recorded on my account for this game includes some exploration while looking for hidden areas and just enjoyng the view - is that a weak point? ;-)
[/list]
[h3]Overall[/h3] 
INSIDE is an outstanding and unique experience that is absolutely worth its asking price. In case you enjoyed the game and are reading this, and by some reason have not heard of [b]Limbo[/b] then please try it! :-)

Another amazing game by Playdead! While not as difficult as their previous one [i]Limbo[/i] this definitely has a grittier and more dystopian feel to it.
The puzzles have evolved slightly with new elements to it like controlling mindless in order to open the path forward for your character. There are also new environments as you‚Äôre now able to swim and control a submarine which gives this side-scroller a needed change in scenery and gameplay.
The story itself is a bit weird to unravel, but the bits that are there are beautifully told through the environment and player interactions. Also, there‚Äôs a secret ending after having found all the collectibles!
While it is definitely a shorter and easier experience than [i]Limbo[/i] all in all, I still enjoyed my time with this game!

[u]Achievements[/u]
Inside has a total of 14 achievements which are all easily obtained by finding and interacting with 14 collectibles hidden throughout the game. After finding all of them you can even achieve a secret ending to the story. With a guide it‚Äôs a very easy 100%!

[b]Note:[/b] The Demo to this game also boasts 14 total achievements which are the main game ones just copy pasted. Surprisingly, after having bought the full game, the demo also lets you play through the entire game, and you can unlock all 14 achievements in the same way again!

My time with Inside may have been brief, but it certainly left a positive impression. As a 2.5D platform game, the aim was to progress from left to right into increasingly dangerous terrain, with various obstacles to overcome. The puzzles were physics based and the story largely ambiguous, depending on the setting to tell a wordless narrative. I was invested for its entirety, absorbing the dread that mounted from the beginning. The whole package was a pleasure to sit through, the scares more quiet and subtle as opposed to aggressive‚Äîparasitic worms, murderous sirens and a grand finale of body horror that came as a delightful surprise.
As far as indie games go with hits and misses, this one I'd consider a gem that didn't overstay its welcome, but rather offered a few hours of immaculately designed gameplay.

Inside is an atmospheric platform game. The colors and backgrounds used in the game excite the player.
The game takes the player to a dystopian world. Encountering obstacles alone, the character explores the environment by overcoming dangers. The sounds used in the game also adapt to the atmosphere. 

In the game, the character tries to escape from invisible beings, long-haired monsters in the water, dog attacks and various explosions. In the game, we can control the brains of zombies whose brains have been removed by connecting them to our own brains with a device. In some parts, our character has to imitate zombies. As far as I understand in the story of the game, an experiment is being carried out on humans. At the beginning of the game there were many dead pigs on the ground. I guess experiments were done on pigs, then it was time for humans. I'm not sure what kind of experimentation was done in the game. I liked how the game made the player actively think. It is enjoyable to be able to manage the character according to the environment and make the character progress by making the right decisions. The challenges in the game are cleverly arranged and they become increasingly difficult to overcome as the game progresses. Although the game is quite enjoyable, there are things I can criticize. 

The game is short. I didn't understand why the monster coming out of the water was trying to kill the character. I didn't understand why the unseen beings were attacking the character or why the dogs were trying to kill the character.

 I didn't like that it was unclear what the character was running from and what exactly the story of the game was. It is a cleverly designed game with its atmosphere, puzzles and visuals. I enjoyed playing. Those who enjoy playing atmospheric puzzle games may prefer it.

Highly recommended for horror game lovers and also adventure gamers. 10/10 for me.
