Disclaimer; I finished the game in one sitting, without looking anything up and it's now almost 2 AM and I have work at 7 in the morning, so it's been quite a night!

Overall verdict: A decent game that overstays its welcome.

The puzzles with the exception of 1 or 2 timing-based ones, pretty much solve themselves.
I would like to say the story seems decent, except there is none.

Much like Limbo, a lot is left to interpretation, except the problem with Inside is that it is too ambitious.
There are various themes of adulthood, losing of self, the great chain, capitalism, loss of innocence and in general, society throughout the entire game.

The issue is that at some point it loses its focus and you lose track of what it wants to be.
And then once you go back and put pieces together, you realize that the story started at a crazy point, with lots of questions and no answers, and as it goes on, there are only more questions added and by the very end, you have exactly 0 answers!

While it was just barely cohesive in the sense of its themes, it loses all of that past a certain point towards the last third of the game, where a sort of "transition happens".

What made Limbo work - despite what a lot of people here seem to be implying against for some reason!? - was that it never lost its cohesion.
You start with a lot of questions but by the end, you can have a general answer for yourself as to what just happened.

It's not trying to convey a message or social commentary on anything, it's very very straight forward.
And the ending for Limbo simply just works, where the ending for Inside is one big floppy mess which if you play through, you know exactly what I'm talking about.

Where Limbo had the sense of rising tension towards the end and by the time you finally make it, your heart is about to explode, it ends with a certain bitter-sweet cathartic end that puts things into perspective.

With Inside, you start the game in a lot of mystery, keep going and get more and more curious, then past the midpoint you start to feel the strain but still want to push through the end, and when something very very horrific happens towards the end, you can not wait to just finish and get it over with, and once you DO reach the very end, you just sit there, mashing your buttons and asking "wait, that was IT!?"

Another key thing is the players ability to integrate into the environment. 

Part of what made Limbo so great was that it didn‚Äôt ever make sense until the last few seconds. 
You never walk through the environment and say ‚Äúoh, yeah, I get it, that‚Äôs normal!‚Äù
It never stops being messed up and it continues to be shocking. 

With Inside, it works the same way during the first half. 
Nothing makes sense and you proceed through with the same sense of curiosity, looking for answers. 
But then it starts losing its focus as time goes on and it only gets worse towards the ending. 

Unlike Limbo, nothing ever starts making sense and it won‚Äôt by the time it ends either. 
The result is that you‚Äôre now accustomed to the absurdity and therefore, desensitized to it, to the point that you stop questioning it. 

There is no logic; never was and never will be, unless you go with a literal Limbo logic which just doesn‚Äôt work here. 

You could make it work if you introduced it right as the very ‚Äúwatery transition‚Äù happens, marking everything before that point the twisted unsolved reality while eveything after is the beyond, but it‚Äôs still just lazy and not fleshed out. 


In regards to the game play, I'd say it's mechanically MILES ahead of Limbo in just about every way.
The physics of everything is designed so unique that even by the time you finish the game, you'll still continue to be surprised by a new physics-based mechanic that you just discovered.

Although what Limbo had going for it was its simplicity.
Enough that I can come back to it after 4 years and play through every bit like it was yesterday that I played it, and it all just works the way you expect it to, the way you know it should!


Here's what I think; towards the last third of the game at the beach with the giant door, I get a sense of overwhelming excitement and an anxious expectation of the unknown; of what awaited me behind that door and how things could end.

It would've been the perfect ending to the game; beyond the great gate, the overwhelming sound of inexplicable horror, something unfathomable, vague yet not unfamiliar, something primal!

And my expectation was subsequently not met as the game goes on for a while, and I mean A WHILE after that and there are so many changes in the theme and atmosphere that all that sense of excitement and anxiety I had were long gone by the time it ended.

I suppose they didn't want to end it like Limbo, with a fantastic build-up and a big bang.
Rather it ends with a big meaty flap, right when you don't expect it, and it's... meaningless!
Just like us, here, now, me writing this at 2 AM on an exhausted brain and you who just read all of this... for what?

Yeah, just go play it!

It's good. I mean this is not the best game I've played even this week, but it's good. The environment felt very unique and I really enjoyed the setting. It was nice to see what the devs could do with very few mechanics over the course of 3.5 hours. The most interesting mechanic is when your character puts on a mind control helmet that lets you control the sheeple nearby. And you have to move them to solve puzzles. 

I struggled with some of the puzzles, but only because I thought the devs were trying to do something cooler than they actually were. For instance, one puzzle involves pushing a button while some giant storage silos fall and roll down a ramp toward you. At one point in the roll down, one of the silos bounces and its door flings open. I thought you had to time it such that you jump into the silo, and roll down with it. But you don't. If you try that you just die. What you have to do is just run really fast and jump down into the water below the ramp. Idk I thought it would've been cooler to jump into the bin rather than just run away. 

There isn't really a story to the game, but there is a twist toward the end that's hilarious. I played the game while travelling in 3 sittings and it was great for that. But again, this is not going to change your life. It's just not that kind of game.

[b]Overall:[b]

INSIDE is everything that LIMBO tried and failed to be, and it's hard to believe that both games are from the same developer.

INSIDE's worldbuilding is eerie and intense, with no background music for majority of the game and only ambient noise, sharp barks and the boy's frantic breaths and pained huffs as he goes on this journey. It presents plenty of questions through beautiful set pieces and high tension moments. I didn't expect body horror going into this game, but they did it justice. 

It's not perfect, of course. There are some moments of jank but it didn't have the tediousness that came with LIMBO. The puzzles aren't obtuse and the none stayed for longer than necessary, which kept them from becoming annoying.

Overall, a great game. Glad I played this after LIMBO or else LIMBO would have been even more of a shitshow for me.

Got this whilst its was on sale for just over ¬£1, best big one I've ever spent. took just over 3 hours to finish and another hour and bit achievement hunting after finishing it once. It's a short and sweet game, you can probably finish it in just one sitting, but it was very impressive the places it took me in those 3 hours. It's akin to Little Nightmares in both gameplay and atmosphere, managing to keep you on edge with some very tense moments and also giving you some breaks in beautifully designed areas to just soak in all the atmosphere. A few moments really stuck with me; namely the decent with the mer-person and, most notably, the Pulse section having some of if not the best sound design I've ever heard in a game with a great build up hearing it get louder and louder from a few areas away, as well as some some wonderful music, which is sparsely used in this game only saving it for key moments.  

Overall an absolute hidden gem of a game that doesn't overstay its welcome. Amazing art direction, a confusing world that feels very satisfying to unravel as you discover more and more secrets as well as some of the best sound design in the industry make for an almost unforgettable experience. Easy 9/10, definitely pick it up if its ever on sale.

Phenomenal, truly. Not going to post much on this review, but seriously go play this. I've unlocked all achievements, found all secrets, found the secret ending, and still play certain memorable parts because they are just so fucking cool man. The best way to describe this game would be; Your own description. This game means different things to different people, from possible symbolism, to governmental surveillance, to just a good story through no words. Speaking of no words; you've heard the saying for films and media: "Show, don't tell," INSIDE takes that saying to heart; there is no dialogue in INSIDE. It is a puzzle game, with no true input form the protagonist, all the way to the scientists later found in the game, aside from the heavy breathing done by the protagonist during stressful parts of the game. INSIDE, to me, has an inspiration from classical books of old times such as; George Orwell's "1984," Aldous Huxley's "Brave New World," and aspects of Ray Bradbury's "Fahrenheit 451." From the empty fields, to the government surveillance, all examples provided do fit in somewhere, and they can be connected to different parts of INSIDE. But don't let this Steam review tell you all you 'need' to know before buying this game. INSIDE is a true masterpiece, one that should be remembered for what it is, and has done. Truly and amazing experience, that anyone who has read this review, should play. If you can take the time to read this, you should take the time to play the game, for this review means nothing compared to the actual game itself. Thank you for reading my review on INSIDE.

Gameplay is pretty straight forward, simple controls, and the puzzles aren't super difficult but are still satisfying to figure out. Very dark in tone and very brutal. You will die a lot, in many different ways. The story is left ambiguous on purpose, some people think it's annoying when a story doesn't make any sense after it's finished, but I think it works with INSIDE just because you can make up your own theory on what the game was about. 
Bought the game on sale but in my opinion it is worth buying at full price.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

This game... This game has caught me on a whole other level. It captured me in a way no other game ever has all while being just a simple 2D side scroller. THAT IS FUCKING CRAZY! I don't want to write an essay on steam so ill just say some short stuff but oh my god. The sound design in this game is like being served a 5 star full course meal, the game is practically just pure masterfully crafted sound design and i fw it so much it's unbelievable. There's sections of the game where the sound physically made me feel the intensity of the current situation, specifically referring to one section where you just got through a door where loud shockwaves could be heard from the other side. Which i instantly proceeded walking right into and got blown to smithereens and it was both so horrifying to witness but also so fucking cool. This is just one of the moments where sound made me get blown away (quite literally) but there's way more times in the game where this happens and i LOVE it! This game has inspired me greatly and i couldn't recommend it more.
